Selective oxidation of 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is significant for the sustainable synthesis of industrially important products such as polyethylene 2,5-furandicarboxylate (PEF). Developing non-precious and proficient catalytic system are of great significance for the biomass-derived HMF to produce FDCA. Herein, we demonstrated a facile synthesis of Fe nanoparticles on NH2-functionalized SBA-15 (FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15) and employed as catalyst for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA. Rate of HMF conversion and FDCA formation over the present catalyst under low oxygen (O2) pressure (0.6 MPa) is investigated in detail. Various parameters such as catalyst loading, temperature, time, solvent, O2 pressure, catalyst regeneration and recyclability, revealed the efficiency of the catalyst with FDCA yield as high as 89.4% at 100% HMF conversion. In addition, the maximum yield of HMFCA was monitored as the FDCA formation and the oxidation reaction proceeds through HMFCA intermediate. Besides, the recyclability of the catalyst demonstrated high stability and reused long life (∼5 cycles). Such a protocol provides an alternative catalytic path to synthesize biomass derived value-added chemicals and intermediates. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 Selective oxidation 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid Heterogeneous conditions 1 Introduction Energy demand and crucial need for environmental benign technologies have focused on minimizing excessive consumption of non-renewable fossil resources by opting biomass renewable resources, sustainable technology and clean energy systems [1–5]. Biomass conversion into valuable intermediates and direct-products are indispensable that forms basic perspective for sustainable environment finding alternative to fossil resources [6,7]. In the last decades, biomass derived 5- hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), led as a main component for the substantial production of various fuels and chemicals [8–11]. In general, there is more scope in creating reaction pathways when dealing with HMF, since various functional groups such as formyl, hydroxyl and furan moiety contributes to different products. Recent advancement in biomass transformation have focused on production and conversion of HMF to valuable derivatives over different catalytic systems progressed through feasible pathways [12–15]. In particular, HMF oxidation leads to the production of many important industrial compounds such as; 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-(hydroxymethyl) furan-2-carboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-formylfuran-2-carboxlic acid (FFCA) and 2,5- furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [16, 17]. In attaining specific product, selective oxidation is considerably vital in the industrial point of view. More essentially, oxidation of HMF to FDCA is considerably prolific as it is an important source as a replacement monomer for petroleum-based terephthalic acid in manufacturing bio-based plastics and other polymer derivatives [18–20]. Compared with the conventional oxidation and homogeneous catalytic systems, which has serious limitations in recyclability and sustainability, heterogeneous catalysts takes prime place. Recently, oxidation of HMF to FDCA has been widely studied over various heterogeneous catalytic systems under different reaction conditions [21–28]. Moreover, the presence of a base is crucial to promote the oxidation/dehydrogenation process of HMF to FDCA [27, 29, 30]. In general, basic sites enable the oxidation of –CHO group to –COOH group and involves in O–H bond breakage [31, 32]. In recent years, heterogeneous solid catalysis is more attractive associated with moderate acid/basic sites, recoverability and reusability. Consequently, in order to increase the FDCA production, more efficient catalytic systems and reaction methodology are obligatory. In this context, many efforts have already been contributed employing noble metals supported catalysts. However, the economic point of view of producing FDCA from HMF still demands novel inexpensive metal-based heterogeneous catalysts. Solid acid/base heterogeneous catalysts with tunable porous properties, tailored acidity or basicity have been investigated to attain remarkable catalytic activity and significant productivity towards biomass conversion [28, 33-35]. Among these, incorporation of transition metal over supported catalysts find its crucial place to offer surface oxidative properties with diverse oxygen species within the system. Such redox properties together with acid/base active sites are vital in achieving selective product. Although high yields of FDCA and catalytic efficiency could be accomplished by the existing methods, the use of noble metals, homogeneous base, and non-generative catalysts limits the methodology in some factor. Based on this state of the art, utilization of recoverable, productive and inexpensive solid base catalysts are considerably desired. With the advent of mesoporous support materials, SBA-15 possess unique properties with high surface area, high porosity and ease of metal incorporation and functionalization [36]. In general SBA-15 retain high-density silanol groups, thick pore walls, and excellent thermal stability those facilitate surface modification with various functional groups [37–39]. Moreover, high dispersion of metal nanoparticles and acid/base functionalization over SBA-15 could be achieved as per the catalytic reaction requirements. Furthermore, oxidation of HMF to FDCA in the presence of a solid base heterogeneous catalyst and subsequent reaction mechanisms have been rarely examined. In addition to catalytic materials, employing economical and sustainable oxidants like O2 in industries is important to avoid complex purification procedures from the product-oxidant mixtures [28, 40, 41]. Most commonly, the active sites on the surface of metal supported catalyst and the competency of oxygen mobility play an important role in oxidation. In view of the above contemplations, the present work has focused on the synthesis and characterization of Fe nanoparticles dispersed NH2 functionalized SBA-15 (FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15) catalyst for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The protocol involves the optimization of reaction conditions such as catalyst amount, reactant-catalyst feed ratio, O2 pressure, temperature, time, and recyclable nature those suitable for FDCA production. The amino group that are functionalized over mesoporous support material and the Fe NPs intact composite structure serves as a beneficial component for superior catalytic activity associated with interaction of reactant/intermediates with the basicity, surface oxidative property and active sites of catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Triblock copolymer EO20PO70EO20 pluronic 123 (P123), tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS), and 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. Sodium borohydride (NaBH4), Iron (III) chloride (FeCl3) and other chemicals used in the investigation were of analytical grade from Alfa Aesar™. Reactant and standards (HMF, HMFCA, FFCA, and FDCA) procured from Sigma–Aldrich were of HPLC grade. All the reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous Si-SBA-15 SBA-15 was synthesized hydrothermally using P123 (EO20PO70EO20) and TEOS as structure directing agent and silica source respectively. Typical synthesis involves the addition of P123 (1 g) and HCl (1 M) at 35 °C followed by TEOS (2 g) under constant stirring for 24 h and the solution was subsequently heated at 100 °C for 24 h [42]. The recovered solid product was filtered, washed with distilled water, and calcined at 800 K for 12 h in muffle furnace. 2.3 Synthesis of NH2-SBA-15 Surface functionalization was done to replace the silanol groups present in the pure sample with other organic functional groups by using alkoxysilanes. As in pure SBA-15 support, only silanol groups exist, those create weak hydrogen bonds with metal nanoparticles and reactant molecules. Hence, surface functionalization of SBA-15 is required to improve the interaction capacity of silica. The modification of SBA-15 with effective NH2- functionalization was carried out using post-grafting technique. For the incorporation of amino-organic moieties, APTMS was used, where pure SBA-15 (2 g) was pretreated at 150 °C for 2 h in a nitrogen atmosphere to remove physisorbed water. After the solid was brought to room temperature under nitrogen, it was suspended in dry toluene (50 ml) and stirred for approximately 30 min. APTMS (2 ml) in toluene (50) was added drop-wise to the slurry and stirred under reflux at 100 °C in an oil bath for 24 h. The product was then filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried overnight at 80 °C under vacuum. The resultant material was dried at 200 °C to remove physisorbed water. The obtained functionalized mesoporous material was designated as NH2-SBA-15. 2.4 Synthesis of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 FeCl3 was used as metal precursor for the synthesis of Fe nanoparticles. 20 mL of 0.1 M metal precursor was added to 100 mg of NH2-SBA-15, and the mixture was sonicated for 4 h at room temperature followed by vacuum drying. Unbound metal precursors on the external surface of SBA 15 were removed by washing with distilled water. Ultrasonic treatment of reduction of metals was performed by dropwise addition of NaBH4 solution (1 M) for 30 min. Mesoporous silica SBA-15 with embedded iron nanoparticles were filtered and dried under vacuum. The obtained pale color solid is denoted as FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15. 2.5 Oxidation of HMF and product analysis The oxidation of HMF was performed in a stainless-steel reactor equipped with electrical heating under O2 pressure (Parr Instrument Co.). Required amount of 5-HMF was dissolved in 20 ml of ultrapure DI water with appropriate quantity of the catalyst on stirring (700 rpm) under optimized pressure. After completion of the reaction, the liquid products were filtered and analyzed by HPLC. HPLC (Agilent Technologies) equipped with photodiode array detector with phenomenex column was employed for the analysis of reaction products. The mobile phase composition was 0.2% H3PO4/water at 25 °C, at a flow rate of 0.8 mL min−1. To acquire reproducible results, each analysis of the liquid products were repeated twice. Quantification of HMF conversion and product yield was done by the following equations on a carbon basis. HMF Conversion ( % ) = n HM F i − n H M F f n HM F i FDCA yield ( % ) = n F D C A n HM F i HMFCA yield ( % ) = n H M F C A n HM F i FFCA yield ( % ) = n F F C A n HM F i Where, HMFi is the initial molar amount of HMF nHMFf is the molar amount of HMF after the reaction nFDCA, nHMFCA and nFFCA are the molar amount of products formed respectively. 2.6 Characterization of catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Rigaku Miniflex II powder X-ray diffractometer with a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å) operating at 30 kV and 15 mA. Diffraction patterns were recorded using a Bruker D8 Focus Advance diffractometer equipped with LynxEye detector with a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Low (0.5 - 8°) diffraction patterns were obtained with a scanning rate of 0.5° - 1° min−1, respectively. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained at 77 K on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 apparatus. The specific surface area of the samples were calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and pore size distribution curves were obtained from the analysis of nitrogen desorption isotherms using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method for mesoporous materials and Horvath–Kawazoe (HK) method for microporous AC. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) of the samples was analyzed by FEI-Quanta FEG instrument comprising FEG assembly with Schottky emitter (−200 V to 30 kV), beam current >100 nA, and 1.2 nm (Gold nano particles suspended on Carbon substrate). TEM characterization was performed using a JEOL 3010 electron microscope operated at 300 kV. Carbon dioxide-Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem II chemisorption analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector where the catalyst was pre-treated under helium flow (20 cm3 min−1) with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 at 400 °C (90 min.) and then CO2 (50 pulses, 1 cm3) diluted in He flow (10 cm3 min−1) was adsorbed at appropriate temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed on an ultra-high vacuum (UHV) multipurpose surface analysis system (Specs™, Germany) employing a conventional X-ray source (XR-50, Specs, Mg Kα, 1253.6 eV). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst characterization FTIR spectra of NH2-SBA-15 and FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 samples are shown in Fig. 1. The broad band around 3420 cm−1 could be attributed to surface silanols and adsorbed water molecules, whose deformational vibrations cause the absorption band near 1637 cm−1. The bands in the range 2900–3000 cm−1 are attributed to the C–H stretching modes of –CH2 in APTMS due to the reaction between the hydroxyl groups of the silica network with the methoxy groups of the APTMS. The broad band appearing at 3292 cm−1 could be attributed to the amine NH stretching vibrations. The absorption bands at 1087, 808, and 464 cm−1 are assigned to asymmetric stretching, symmetric stretching, and bend stretching of Si−O−Si groups [42,43]. Adsorption bands at 1605 and 2926 cm−1 are due to N–H bending and methylic vibrations, indicating that the amino group was confined within the SBA-15 channels, rather than adsorbed onto the surface [44]. Low angle (0.5–5°) and high angle (10–80°) powder-XRD patterns of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 are shown in Fig. 1. Due to the presence of Fe nanoparticles and amine molecules in SBA-15 surface, low angle diffraction peaks at (110) and (200) could not be observed in Fig. 2a. Instead, like other mesoporous SBA-15 type materials FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 sample displayed an intense, low angle 2θ peak at 0.6° corresponding to the (100) plane. Presence of this characteristic diffraction peak suggests that the mesopore structure is still preserved even after the Fe metal nanoparticles dispersion within the NH2 functionalized mesoporous support. In the high-angle XRD patterns (Fig. 2b) of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 showed a hump at 2θ ∼20°, due to amorphous silica. Besides, Fe nanoparticles showed different diffraction peaks in XRD and the distinct peak located around 44° and 64° belongs to the Fe cubic phase (JCPDS No, 89–7194) [45]. Fig. 3a shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 materials. The respective isotherms of the materials represent typical type IV isotherms with H1 hysteresis loop characteristic of mesoporous material with regular pore structure. The adsorption isotherm of SBA-15 shows a sharp increase around P/Po = 0.6, suggesting that the capillary condensation of nitrogen occur inside a uniform mesopore structure, well in accordance with the low-angle XRD pattern observations. Pore structural properties confirms the amine accommodation successfully impregnated into the pores of the SBA-15 support. Pore size distribution are calculated using desorption branch of the isotherms by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method (Fig. 3b). The pore size were distributed in the range of 2.8 nm with pore volume of 0.53 cm3/g, which indicates that the grafting also narrowed the pore size distribution. Fig. 4a shows SEM image of material with large thread like structures 20–30 µm and 3–5 µm in length and diameter respectively. The fibrous/thread structure is an agglomerate of long fibers that are constituted from small rod-like sub-particles 1–2 µm in length and 0.5 µm in diameter. Figs. 4b & 4c represents the typical HRTEM images of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 which showed regular hexagonal pore structure with long range ordering and long channels with the cylindrical pores arranged in an ordered hexagonal array. The pores of the rod-like sub-particles run parallel to the long axis of the rod. As observed in the figures, well-defined 2D-hexagonal symmetry is clearly seen, and the pore diameter is estimated to be ∼9 nm. Moreover, Fe nanoparticles embedded in channels of SBA-15 are clearly observed. After the ultrasound irradiation, formations of uniformly distributed small spherical Fe nanoparticles particles with average size ∼6 nm, within the pores of SBA-15, are observed. The sizes of the nanoparticles inside the pores are close to the pore diameters of SBA-15. Well-ordered hexagonal arrays of mesoporous channels within the material confirmed the 2D p6mm hexagonal structure (a characteristic of SBA-15), even after NH2 functionalization and distribution of Fe NPs. Basicity of the catalyst was investigated using CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) as it is the powerful technique for analyzing the basic sites on the solid surface of the material. In general, the desorption peaks at different escalating temperatures could be attributed to weak, medium and strong basic sites [46]. Fig. 5 shows the CO2-TPD of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 possess weak-medium low-temperature TPD peak centered at 280 °C, which indicates that there exist medium basic sites those chemisorbed by CO2 with basicity of 0.24 mmol CO2/g catalyst. The catalyst was further characterized by XPS to determine the elemental composition and oxidation state. Fig. 6 shows the XPS of Si2p, O1s, N1s, and Fe2p for FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst. The Si 2p spectrum of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 shows a peak centered at binding energy 103.5 eV, which is assigned to the characteristic of silicates (Fig. 6a). O 1 s spectra revealed the peak centered at 532.4 eV attributing to oxygen species in the catalytic material (Fig. 6b). N 1 s spectra represents a peak at 401.7 eV indicating the presence of nitrogen and that the amino group was successfully functionalized over SBA-15 support (Fig. 6c). The characteristic peaks with binding energy at 723.2 eV and 710.1 eV are assigned to Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 respectively (Fig. 6d). From the observation, presence of Fe2+, and Fe3+ oxidation states could be evident. Fe2p XPS for the recycled catalyst was characterized and presented in Fig. 6e. For the recycled catalyst, the Fe2+ and Fe3+ species contributes to be involved in the reaction, where the Fe3+(Fe 2P1/2) exist in slightly higher proportion after oxidation process during the reaction. 3.2 Catalytic performance on HMF oxidation Oxidation of HMF takes place over a number of catalysts under various oxidants those acting as an electron acceptor to form main compounds such as; DFF, FFCA, HMFCA, and FDCA (Scheme 1 .) [17]. As per the literature reports, the transformation of HMF upon oxidation comprehends complex reaction routes as tracking a specific product is a stimulating challenge. In specific, FDCA formation from HMF oxidation needs a vital catalytic system to achieve high productivity. Here we performed the HMF oxidation over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst and O2 as oxidant. Initially, blank reactions were carried out without any catalyst. In these cases, no oxidation products were determined by HPLC and HMF quantification was high. These indicated that catalyst active sites for the oxidation of HMF is required and that the HMF is stable under catalyst-free conditions applied. Moreover, employing non-noble metal nanostructures and solid base catalysts to improve HMF oxidation process is an important task. In order to ascertain the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst, various reaction parameters was optimized. The effects on amount of catalyst, choice of solvent, O2 pressure, reaction time, reaction temperature on HMF conversion and FDCA yield were precisely investigated. It is proposed that Fe NPs accounts for the surface oxidative property and controls the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, while the NH2 functional groups provides basic sites within the SBA-15 matrix that initiates the formation of diol by the attack on hydroxide ion of aldehyde in HMF [45]. Such type of structural co-ordination is apt for the stable oxidation process to yield FDCA. To elucidate the activity of the catalysts, oxidation of HMF was studied over various catalysts (Table 1 ). When H-Mordenite and γ-alumina were employed, FDCA yield was only 13.4% and 3.6% for a conversion of 68% and 61%, respectively, hence supporting the activity of present mesoporous catalyst. Without any catalyst, the reaction hesitated to proceed and with Si-SBA-15 alone, merely 12% HMF conversion with less than 1% FDCA was observed. FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst showed a complete conversion of HMF with maximum selectivity toward FDCA. Such a catalytic activity proves the necessity of the solid oxidative active sites (from FeNPs) with moderate basicity (from NH2 O-Si-) associated with mesoporous support for the oxidation reaction. Moreover, easier diffusion of the reactant-intermediate (large organic molecules) through mesopores of silica matrix occurs without precipitation problems that are more probable in conventional homogeneous catalysts [47,48]. It could be stated that the formation of product could be due to the availability of –CHO and CH2OH group in HMF for the active sites of FeNPs dispersed NH2-silica matrix to undergo selective oxidation. Catalyst amount also had significant effect on the oxidation of HMF as the dosage of catalyst to HMF substrate is a decisive factor for the optimization. Fig. 7a shows the HMF conversion, FDCA yield with respective to the amount of catalyst. Respective conversion and FDCA yield for catalyst quantity varied in the range from 20 mg to 80 mg. FDCA yield of 59.7% for 67.1% HMF conversion was observed initially for 20 mg catalyst. When the catalyst loading increased, FDCA drastically increased at higher rate, where 40 mg catalyst offered full conversion and 77.2% of FDCA yield. On further increase of catalyst loading to 60 mg, maximum yield was attained and for 80 mg catalyst weight, FDCA yield declined. This could be due to the higher concentration of catalyst that would lead to side reactions. Hence, the feed of 60 mg catalyst was observed to be optimum to afford higher yield toward FDCA. To enhance the product yield, the oxidation of HMF was conducted in various solvents. Effects of solvents on the conversion of HMF and yields of FDCA using FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst are shown in Fig. (7b). FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 mesoporous catalyst were highly active for the conversion of HMF in water. Water with high polar nature and good solubility were found to be the best solvent, and the HMF conversion was 100% and offered 89.4% FDCA, respectively. However, the yield of FDCA in MeCN, DMF, and DMSO was observed to be lower even though the conversion was high. This might be due to the absorption of solvent-reactant intermediates over mesoporous silica support in these solvents. Other solvents such as methanol, ethanol, methanol-water, ethanol-water, and dioxane, could only provide lower conversion with lesser yields of FDCA. Further, with aromatic solvents such as toluene, benzene and ethylbenzene, the oxidation did not offer full HMF conversion and the FDCA yield was far less. This could be due to the availability of active sites around the substrate molecules in water is more pronounced under O2 atmosphere without steric hindrance. The influence of reaction rates indicated that the conversion and product profiles were superior when water was used as solvent. In particular, HMF degradation to glycolic acid is a main concern in the presence of water and this was well controlled under O2 pressure in the present catalytic system, as the glycolic acid was undetected in the reactions. The influence of O2 pressure on HMF oxidation was investigated and Fig. 8 shows the HMF conversion and FDCA yield for the corresponding O2 pressure from 0.2 to 1.2 MPa. The conversion was stable on varied O2 pressures and the FDCA yield increased with O2 pressure from 0.2 to 1.2 MPa and maintained saturation until 1.0 MPa. By employing 0.6 MPa of O2, the oxidation offered maximum FDCA yield under the given conditions. The effects of reaction time on HMF conversion and yield of products were studied over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst (Fig. 9a). The oxidation of HMF at 120 °C was monitored from 1 to 16 h reaction time and it was found that the formation of FDCA was identified after 2 h. For HMF conversion of 35.5%, the yield of HMFCA, FFCA and FDCA were 17.3%, 15.6% and 2.6%, after 2 h respectively. From 4 to 6 h, FDCA yield started to increase in a larger rate from 15.5% to 39.9%. It was observed that with the extension of reaction time to 8 h, HMF was completely converted (100%), with the yields of 34.8%, 10.9% and 54.3%, toward HMFCA, FFCA and FDCA. From the experimental results, it is clear that the yields of HMFCA and FFCA decreased while that of FDCA reached the maximum at 14 h. An intense observation on reaction route followed by time study revealed that the FDCA formation occurred through HMFCA and FFCA transformations. With further increase of reaction time (14 h to 16 h), FDCA yield slightly decreased by the degradation of FDCA to other by-products. Hence, the optimal reaction time of 14 h is suitable for selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst. In addition, it was found that at the lower time period, significant increase of HMFCA yield persisted denoting that both –CHO group and –OH group in HMF could be made reactive over the present catalyst. It has been reported that DFF was the main intermediate when the HMF oxidation reaction takes place in the absence of a base [49]. In the present catalytic system, no DFF was found stating that the reaction path proceeds through HMFCA route, which also could be due to the basicity of solid catalyst as confirmed by CO2-TPD study. Under the optimal reaction time of 14 h, the reactions were conducted at different reaction temperatures (90 to 160 °C). The effects of reaction temperature on the oxidation of HMF over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 in water under O2 atmosphere are shown in Fig. 9b. The catalytic activity of the representative catalyst persistently ascended on increasing the temperature. Initially at 90 °C, the conversion rate of HMF was 96.7%, and the yield of HMFCA, FFCA and FDCA were 38.3%, 31.3% and 27.1%, respectively. When the temperature increased to 100 °C, HMF was completely converted, and the yield of FDCA increased to 45.3% with 32.2% HMFCA, and 22.5% FFCA. At this stage, one can observe that at lower temperatures, HMFCA and FFCA pronounced well and HMFCA was higher comparatively. When temperature was increased to 120 °C, FDCA yield reached a maximum of 89.4% with other by-products FFCA (4.4%) and HMFCA (5.2%) for fully converted HMF at 14 h. HMF oxidation proceeded well with least amount of by-products to claim this temperature to be optimal for the present catalytic system. On further increasing the temperature to 140 °C, FDCA yield slightly declined with 88.7% and at 160 °C, FDCA yield was found to be 87.5%. Hence, the optimal reaction temperature for synthesis of FDCA through HMF oxidation was found to be at 120 °C. As per the acquired results, HMFCA and FFCA with higher yields at low temperatures and those with lower yields at high temperatures could be well observed that an efficient transformation to FDCA ensued. Apart from these by-products, the carbon balance decreased due to the degradation of formed intermediates at high temperatures (>120 °C) due to the over-oxidation and the inferior thermal stability of intermediates in the solution [50]. As mentioned in previous reports, decrease in the yield of FDCA at higher temperatures might be due to the degradation to humins and other unknown by-products [51,52]. However, FDCA yield was still higher among the oxidation products over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 from 140 °C to 160 °C. Nonetheless, carbon balances (> 99%) were higher in HMF oxidation from 90 °C to 120 °C revealing the efficiency of catalytic system and the present protocol principally account for higher FDCA yields under specified optimal reaction conditions over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst. Catalytic activity of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 on HMF oxidation to FDCA is compared with previously reported catalysts in Table S1. In order to check the maximum yield of HMFCA at low temperatures, we optimized the reaction conditions to get more clear insight. Interestingly, HMFCA with yield as high as 71.2% was obtained at 80 °C for 8 h using 30 mg of catalyst when the reactions were performed on varying catalyst amount. Thus, HMFCA is formed even at lower temperatures for lower catalyst loading i.e., milder reaction conditions. In other words, HMFCA transformation into FDCA takes place at higher oxidation rate (i.e., depending on temperature, oxidant, catalyst) whereas HMFCA formation needs a milder oxidation and low temperature conditions. This inclination was realized while performing the reaction target of FDCA also confirming major intermediate (HMFCA) involved in the FDCA formation mechanism. Intensely, such an oxidative transformation helps in constructing a plausible reaction path of HMF oxidation to FDCA, considering the evidence of HMFCA formation as intermediate. As per the mechanistic insights, oxidation of both CH2 OH group and C = O group in HMF is needed to the formation of FDCA. In HMF oxidation through HMFCA, further oxidation of the alcohol group in HMFCA is required to convert into FDCA and this needs a basic catalytic system. More importantly in previous reports, basic sites of the catalyst played a crucial role in HMFCA into FDCA conversion, as observed in the present work [53, 54]. Specifically, when employing metal-based catalyst for HMF oxidation there is a necessity of strong base as additives to attain high yield of FDCA [55]. A plausible mechanism of HMF oxidation to FDCA over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 is presented in Scheme 2 . In the perspective of corrosive nature, complication in purifying the product and non-reusable nature makes a way to find alternate catalytic materials with recyclable solid base type catalysts [56]. In such a context, the present mesoporous FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst provides a new space to convert HMF molecules to FDCA without use of homogeneous base. Usually, base additives were employed when using metal oxide catalysts in the selective 5-HMF oxidation reaction. For instance, under O2 pressure conditions, FDCA from 83% to 91.0% yield was observed over a metal oxides in the presence of strong bases [57,58]. Also, homogeneous Pt@PVP catalyst in the presence of liquid base as additive afforded 95% FDCA yield [59]. As an alternative, this work proved the necessity and productivity of heterogeneous FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 mesoporous catalyst that functions as initial efficient activator of HMF to form reactively-formed HMFCA [60]. Following the optimized method, recyclability of the catalyst was performed to determine its life span as it is significant in practical application. After the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and reused for each cycle. As can be seen from Fig. 10 , HMF conversion rate was 100% and the FDCA yield on increasing number of cycles from 1 to 5 reached 87.2%. The metal content of the catalyst after 5 cycles was detected by ICP-AES, and it was found that only a sub-marginal FeNPs leaching could be occurred (ca. <0.07%) that didn't certainly affect the productivity largely. Moreover, the mesoporous features of the reused catalyst remained identical to fresh catalyst as evidenced by N2 sorption isotherm with pore size distribution (Fig. 11 a). The pore size (2.8 nm), and pore volume (0.53 cm3/g) remain unaltered which shows the structural stability of the catalyst. In addition, the basicity of the catalyst observed to be in the actual range as compared to the fresh catalyst representing the prevailing functionalized –NH2 groups remained intact as confirmed by CO2-TPD measurements (0.22 mmol /g) (Fig. 11b). Hence, no apparent deactivation as well as the properties of the catalyst was noticed, revealing the stable recycling nature. 4 Conclusions Imperatively, synthesizing more efficient, non-precious, economical and reusable solid base-redox catalyst in oxidation reactions, such as monometallic FeNPs over NH2- functionalized mesoporous supports, are still vital. This work demonstrates the fabrication of mesoporous FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 via facile hydrothermal method and the employment of the catalyst over HMF oxidation under O2 atmosphere (0.6 MPa). NH2- functionality over the mesoporous silica SBA-15 expedited a strong interaction with intact FeNPs within the support. Moderate basicity, surface oxidative property and porous features of FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 offered 89.4% FDCA with full HMF conversion on optimizing temperature, O2 pressure, reaction time, solvent and catalyst loading. Moreover as per the reaction trend, systematic path was predicted that followed through HMFCA route to achieve FDCA and hence the efforts were taken to find the maximum yield of HMFCA (71.2% under different reaction conditions) with the same catalytic system. Such a progression in the catalysis field associated with porous features, product selective active sites and surface-oxidative property would stimulate biomass-based conversion to value added chemicals. coredata.dc:description: Selective oxidation of 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is significant for the sustainable synthesis of industrially important products such as polyethylene 2,5-furandicarboxylate (PEF). Developing non-precious and proficient catalytic system are of great significance for the biomass-derived HMF to produce FDCA. Herein, we demonstrated a facile synthesis of Fe nanoparticles on NH2-functionalized SBA-15 (FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15) and employed as catalyst for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA. Rate of HMF conversion and FDCA formation over the present catalyst under low oxygen (O2) pressure (0.6 MPa) is investigated in detail. Various parameters such as catalyst loading, temperature, time, solvent, O2 pressure, catalyst regeneration and recyclability, revealed the efficiency of the catalyst with FDCA yield as high as 89.4% at 100% HMF conversion. In addition, the maximum yield of HMFCA was monitored as the FDCA formation and the oxidation reaction proceeds through HMFCA intermediate. Besides, the recyclability of the catalyst demonstrated high stability and reused long life (∼5 cycles). Such a protocol provides an alternative catalytic path to synthesize biomass derived value-added chemicals and intermediates.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient oxidation of 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid over FeNPs@NH2-SBA-15 catalyst in water
